column3: str
Baderon, proprietor of the Drowning Wench, wants you to perform three tasks that will help you learn the fundamentals of adventuring.
Baderon has given you three tasks to perform. As you make your way around Limsa Lominsa, try approaching citizens who appear to be in need of help.
You have completed all three tasks. Report back to Baderon at the Drowning Wench.
Baderon explains that the three locations you visited will prove indispensable in your adventuring life. Heed well his advice, and travel further afield as your experience grows.

Attune yourself to the aetheryte found on the Lower Decks.
Listen to Swozblaet's explanation of the markets.
Visit the Marauders' Guild.
Report to Baderon at the Drowning Wench.

Right, then. Let's start ye off nice and easy with three tasks what'll 'elp ye settle into yer life 'ere in Limsa.
Firstly, if ye 'ead down a floor then point yer nose to the west, ye'll get an eyeful o' the great glowin' crystal in middle o' the courtyard.
That's an aetheryte─a device what moves ye from one place to another. When ye need to be somewhere in a bleedin' 'urry, there's no swifter way to travel.
'Ave a chat with the Yellowjacket on guard and ye'll be treated to a lecture on the workin's o' the device. Afore that though, ye should try slappin' yer mitts on the crystal itself.
Second on the list is the marketplace. Ye'll find weapons and armor and all yer 'venturin' bits and pieces for sale in the district what lies beyond the aetheryte.
There's more to the markets than just throwin' yer coin around, so be sure ye 'ave a word with Swozblaet, the 'ead o' the Merchants' League.
Give 'im this rusty old octant, and 'e'll know ye've come from me.
For the last o' me 'elpful 'ints, I suggest ye meet some fellow axe-wielders at the Marauders' Guild.
Ye'll be sure to learn a few new tricks fer swingin' that skull-chopper if ye decide to join their crew. Blauthota at the front desk is the one to get ye started.
Alright, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>? That ought to give ye a fair run about the city and show ye some o' the sights while yer at it.
Curse me, I almost forgot me most useful advice: there's no 'arm in stoppin' to listen to some poor sod's sob story.
Might be that it sounds more of a chore, but ye never know what interestin' tasks or tales are hidin' out there, just waitin' fer ye to crack open the lid.

Aye, ye'll likely be naught more'n an <If(PlayerParameter(4))>errand-girl<Else/>errand-boy</If> at the outset, but after ye build a reputation as people can trust, the jobs'll get 'arder and more rewardin'. That's the road to becomin' a truly grand adventurer.
Ah, another novice adventurer. Aye, I have seen more than a few of your type visiting the aetheryte at Baderon's instruction.
I am Sundhimal, one of the Yellowjackets assigned to keeping the peace in Limsa Lominsa. It is also my charge to provide guidance in the use of this device. Fear not; I shall be brief.
Aetherytes are crystalline structures that tap into aetherial energies, and are primarily used as a means to travel swiftly from one place to another.
Return and Teleport─the most common transportation spells─make direct use of the aetherytes and their connection to the flow of aether.
And as these devices are found in almost every corner of Eorzea, any adventurer worthy of the name will wish to seek out and attune <If(PlayerParameter(4))>herself<Else/>himself</If> to each one.
Once you have expanded your horizons beyond the walls of the city, you will soon find yourself performing the act of attunement as a matter of due course.
There is, however, no need for unseemly haste. You shall find that the aetherytes found in and around the city will be sufficient for the present.
Should you wish to learn more about the aetheryte or transportation magic, I am here to answer your questions.

You attune with the aetheryte.
You are now able to use the Return spell!

A fine <If(LessThan(PlayerParameter(11),12))><If(LessThan(PlayerParameter(11),4))>evening<Else/>morning</If><Else/><If(LessThan(PlayerParameter(11),17))>day<Else/>evening</If></If> to you, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>madam<Else/>sir</If>! Welcome to the most replete marketplace in the grand realm of Eorzea, where our shelves are fit to bursting with practical goods and wondrous treasures from across the seven seas!

Pray browse the stalls until your eyeballs ache from the abundance of unbelievable bargains! Now, as much as I would dearly love to further expound on the unrivaled quality of our merchandise, I must tend to a cargo but newly arrived at the docks─
Hm? You bear to me a octant from the hands of Baderon himself? By the Navigator, I must have left it behind in the Wench, along with a week's pay and several bell's worth of intoxicated memories!
I am most grateful to have it back! This tool is a keepsake from my days as a ship captain, you see. You shall have recompense, and what better coin to receive than the wisdom of a master merchant!
If it is simple and sturdy adventuring equipment you seek, you needn't go further than the East and West arms of Hawkers' Alley.
Should you wish to prepare for battle, equipping oneself with the best arms and armor one can afford is always gil well spent.
Hawkers' Alley has myriad stalls that specialize in the tools of war and offer you your choice of quality weaponry or protective gear.
And within but a few steps are bazaars and apothecaries that will most amply supply all your potion and perishable needs.
Our keen-eyed agents procure a befuddling range of wares during their sojourns to distant shores, thus it pays to become familiar with the type─and price─of the goods stocked by each particular shop.
Such knowledge will serve you well if your purse is light or your time is short.
Shall I continue with this verbal instruction? Nay, I say more value is to be gained by wandering the markets yourself. Experience, even when bitter, is the surest teacher!
Ho there, adventurer. Curious about the Marauders' Guild, are ye?

Any axe worth wieldin' needs two hands on the haft an' has a blade what can chop clean through a galley's mast. That's the kind o' weapon our members train to use with deceptive swiftness an' brutal force.
Are ye interested in hearin' more, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>? Then why don't I give ye the short version o' the guild's foundin' history an' we can go from there.
It all started with ships, ye see. What's that got to do with axes, ye ask? Well, ye won't be makin' many sea vessels without a sturdy tool to lop down trees for the lumber.

An' since only the Navigator Herself knows when a ship'll run afoul of a storm or worse, it makes sense for the crew's carpenter to carry an axe on board. Aye, it all started with shipbuildin' an' ship repair. What? Am I borin' ye?

Well now, any tool on a ship can become a weapon. An' the axe was perfect for hookin' yerself over the rail of an enemy vessel, lettin' loose in a whirl o' steel, an' generally layin' waste to all about ye.

As more seafarers took up the axe as their weapon o' choice, so did the savage art o' the marauder begin to take shape─especially among the pirates where strength an' skill decided yer place in the world.

With an eye to assemblin' crews o' battle-ready raiders, the pirates started teachin' the proper way to wield a choppin' blade to their new recruits. This be how the Marauders' Guild first sprung into bein'.
But once the Galadion Accord was signed to unite the Maelstrom an' the pirates against Limsa Lominsa's enemies, the whole game changed.

The accord itself was a dismal failure o' course, but the Marauders' Guild was never the same─it was taken over, restructured, an' purged of its pirate roots. It had been reborn as an institution dedicated to naught but the teachin' of axe fightin'.
The members o' this new Marauders' Guild weren't no greed-driven cutthroats neither, but warriors what sought to contribute to society with martial prowess.
If masterin' the axe is yer heart's desire, then ye'll find no better arena in which to practice yer swings.
Think it over, then let me know if ye decide to join our ranks. I've a feelin' I'll be seein' more o' ye soon, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>.
Ah, there ye are, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>. Ye back from yer jaunt around the city, then?
If ye mean to base yerself in Limsa Lominsa, that won't be the last time ye'll visit them three places.
And now ye've got some idea o' which way's up, ye can start explorin' the rest o' the town.
Ye've shown a good ear fer listenin', <If(PlayerParameter(4))>lass<Else/>lad</If>. Ye stick with ol' Baderon, and we'll see how far we can take ye.
